title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF Emergency Dpt

description.narrative: Département Sud et Sud-Est.

L'expérience a démontré qu'Haiti est très vulnérable aux épidémies, en témoigne l'epidemie de cholera au cours de laquelle plus de 820 000 cas suspects on été recensés entre 2010 et 2019 et qui a fait plus de 10 000 morts selon le MSPP. Cette pandemie de Covid-19 s'inscrit donc dans un contexte sanitaire déjà très précaire avec des conséquences potentiellement dramatiques pour la population haïtienne, particulièrement les ménages les plus vulnérables qui ont vu leur situation socio-économique et sanitaire se dégrader continuellement depuis le début l'année 2018.

Les enfants, les femmes et leurs familles dans les zones rurales et urbaines, utilisent des services améliorés d'eau, assainissement et hygiène équitables et durables, contribuant à la réduction de l'incidence de la Covid-19 en Haïti.
Population la plus vulnerable dans le département du Sud et Sud-Est en Haïti.
Surveillance et sensibilisation auprès des communautés concernant la pandemie Covid-19 dans les départements du Sud et Sud-Est, Haiti.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
COVID-19 Response & Capacity Strengthening Khartoum

description.narrative: 98,000 persons and indirectly to over 790,000 individuals in Khartoum.
Beneficiaries are mainly from the communities in Omdurman city, Umbada localities and Albougaa administrative unit.

Support to SRCS Khartoum Branch to slow down the fast spreading COVID-19 pandemic and to support the Branch with capacity strengthening. The project will directly deliver assistance to approximately 98,000 persons and indirectly to over 790,000 individuals. In the initial phase, beneficiaries will majorly be from the communities in Omdurman city, Umbada localities, Albougaa administrative unit. SRCS volunteers, health facilities clients and staff are among the beneficiaries.

The most affected locality by COVID-19 in Sudan is Khartoum (city) with 8168 confirmed cases. The state has 239 Primary Health Care centers (PHCs) and only 54% of them are functional. The reasons for non-functioning PHCS is not yet known. Khartoum isolation centers have bed capacity of 646 while ICU bed capacity is 18. This scenario shows the low capacity of the health system in Khartoum (city) to respond to an increasing ratio of COVID-19 cases.

The proposed intervention will support 9 health centres in Khartoum with trainings for staff and volunteers, provision of safe water, PPE’s, hygiene promotion in the community and surveillance. In addition to the COVID-19 response, the proposed intervention also supports the Khartoum branch of SRCS in capacity strengthening, financial sustainability and volunteers management to ensure long-term sustainable support.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Building community resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses in Terekeka County, South Sudan

description.narrative: 43,500 people in Terekeka County (8670 households)

A Resilience Index Measurement and Analysis methodology was applied in 2019 to understand how South Sudanese households cope with shocks and stressors. According to the Resilience Capacity Index Terekeka County has one of the lowest resilience capacities in South Sudan. In Terekeka County about 136,600 people are in great humanitarian need (55%). The most prevalent shocks experienced by households, such as unusually high food prices, irregular rains, prolonged dry spells, reduced income for household members, and insecurity or violence, have a significant negative effect on resilience. The number of people in great humanitarian need is likely to further increase in 2020 because of increased mobility amongst IDPs and spontaneous return of refugees.

Enable 8670 Households - 43,350 vulnerable people to build resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses through targeted programming to increase access to WASH basic services and livelihoods and reduce protection concerns in Terekeka County (South Sudan) in a span of one and half years.

This Intervention will target 4 Payams and 11 Bomas in Terekeka County: 1. Terekeka (Buko, Nyikabor, Juba Bayak and Bor) 2. Muni (Yukara and Gabuta) 3. Reggo (Mogiri Guk, Buju and Buranga) 4. Nyori (Lwoki and Nyori)

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Conflict and Pandemic Preparedness and Response Capacity in Ethiopia

description.narrative: Ethiopia is among countries highly vulnerable to man-made and natural hazards such as conflict, drought, flood, epidemic and pandemic. Conflict and violence in Ethiopia lead to massive displacement and high humanitarian needs. Government reforms have fueled the increasingly ethnically motivated and politicized tensions. There is a high risk that the national election in 2020 will ignite additional outbreaks of violence, likely affecting 3.3 million people nationwide. Moreover, the current COVID-19 pandemic is another risk the country is facing. Humanitarian agencies, including the Ethiopian Red Cross Society (ERCS), have minimum preparedness and response capacities in place to meet the immediate needs, while facing increased difficulty in accessing people in need due to shortage of PPEs, security constraints and the politicization of the situation. The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a timely and principled humanitarian response to people affected by conflict and COVID-19 in Ethiopia, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the ERCS to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs in conflict and other hazards (including COVID-19). The Action will target the ERCS branches in three regions: Amhara, Oromia and SNNP. Activities address technical capacity, systems and procedures, and logistics and include topics that are critical in a context of conflict and other hazards, such as contingency planning; communication and coordination; safer access and protection, and early warning/early action. By supporting the development and countrywide familiarization of key response preparedness policies and guidelines, the Action also contributes to the ERCS’s overall capacity. This Action is a partnership between the Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC) (lead), ERCS, Danish Red Cross (DRC) and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC).

Concerning ‘Conflict and Pandemic Preparedness and Response Capacity in Ethiopia’ The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a timely and principled humanitarian response to people affected by conflict and COVID-19 in Ethiopia, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the ERCS to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs in conflict and other hazards (including COVID-19)

Ethiopia is among countries highly vulnerable to man-made and natural hazards such as conflict, drought, flood, epidemic and pandemic. Conflict and violence in Ethiopia lead to massive displacement and high humanitarian needs. Government reforms have fueled the increasingly ethnically motivated and politicized tensions. There is a high risk that the national election in 2020 will ignite additional outbreaks of violence, likely affecting 3.3 million people nationwide. Moreover, the current COVID-19 pandemic is another risk the country is facing. Humanitarian agencies, including the Ethiopian Red Cross Society (ERCS), have minimum preparedness and response capacities in place to meet the immediate needs, while facing increased difficulty in accessing people in need due to shortage of PPEs, security constraints and the politicization of the situation. The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a timely and principled humanitarian response to people affected by conflict and COVID-19 in Ethiopia, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the ERCS to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs in conflict and other hazards (including COVID-19). The Action will target the ERCS branches in three regions: Amhara, Oromia and SNNP. Activities address technical capacity, systems and procedures, and logistics and include topics that are critical in a context of conflict and other hazards, such as contingency planning; communication and coordination; safer access and protection, and early warning/early action. By supporting the development and countrywide familiarization of key response preparedness policies and guidelines, the Action also contributes to the ERCS’s overall capacity.

Strengthening the Preparedness and Response Capacity of ERCS in particular in Amhara, Oromiya and SNNP regions to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs of conflict-and pandemic/epidemic (COVID-19) affected populations with unreserved access.

Contribution to the Sahel Cluster Operational Plans of 2021 and 2022

description.narrative: Contribution to the Sahel Cluster Operational Plans of 2021 and 2022 NLRC funding source: Block Grant 2018-2021 - Chronic Crises

The rapid deterioration of the Sahel crisis has driven humanitarian needs across the region to unprecedented levels. In 2020 a new record high of 24 million Sahelians in need of life-saving assistance and protection due to conflicts, climate shocks, chronic vulnerabilities, and endemic poverty1. This situation led more people than ever before to flee their homes. In the Sahel, climate change, food insecurity, poverty, conflict, and violence have converged and are overwhelming the lives of millions of people. Mounting humanitarian need is the most visible symptom of the triple peril of severe-weather related disasters, poverty and insecurity plaguing the region. COVID-19 has made the situation even worse.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
SHO campaign contribution to LRCS Response on Beirut Explosion

description.narrative: Beirut, Lebanon
Lebanese Red Cross and Netherlands Red Cross

On August 4th 2020, an explosion took place in the harbor of Beirut, leading to more than 4000 people being injured, and more than 100 deaths. Many houses are destroyed, and the destruction of the harbor complicates arrival of goods most necessary in times of economic crisis and the covid-19 pandemic. In response a SHO (GIRO 555) campaign was organized within the Netherlands. This project facilitates a contribution from the SHO campaign to the LRCS Response on the Beirut Explosion.
SHO campaign contribution to LRCS Response on Beirut Explosion

The project is a contribution from the SHO campaign to the appeal of the Lebanese Red Cross in response to the 2020 Beirut Explosion. The following clusters will benefit from the SHO campaign: a) Cash (Cash Voucher Assistance to beneficiaries) b) Health (Equipment, consumables and other material for emergency medical services, blood transfusion centers, medical social, operational costs for responding to needs) c) Basic Assistance & WASH

3FM SR 2020: COVID-19

description.narrative: The Red Cross focusses on national- and international aid, aiming to relieve the immense pressure on the health care systems and striving to ensure that everyone receives the medical attention that they need wherever and whenever necessary, so also during the corona crisis. The Red Cross has two main objectives: 1. To support and enhance health care centres, doctors’ practices and hospitals by offering them a helping hand, providing logistical support and by sharing knowledge and resources. This gives them more time with their patients and gives them the opportunity to help more people in need. 2. To fight the rise of the coronavirus and to cut down the number of infections, thereby reducing the number of patients in need of medical attention.

description.narrative: Displaced populations currently depend on already limited access to clean, safe, and potable drinking water and water for domestic use in the host communities. If not controlled, it may bring competition and violence to access this scarce commodity between the refugees and the host communities. title.narrative: Response Floods and Typhoons Philippines 2020

description.narrative: 1 Nov Super Typhoon Goni Category 5 made its first landfall over Bato, Catanduanes causing significant damage to shelter, agriculture and infrastructure. 11 Nov Typhoon Vamco made its first landfall in the vicinity of Patnanungan, Quezon causing flash floods, landslides and severe flooding in Rizal Province and Mariquina City, National Capital Region.
120,000 people of the most vulnerable affected households
Assistance to the communities affected by Super Typhoon Goni and Typhoon Vamco in Northern Luzon.
Northern Luzon.

Targeted families will be assisted through interventions in shelter, livelihoods and basic needs, health, WASH, disaster risk reduction, community engagement and accountability as well as protection, gender and inclusion. Teams will adhere and practice all precautionary measures outlined in the Asia Pacific COVID-19-safe Best Practice Guide for Disaster response. The operation will be delivered in a manner that minimizes the risk of COVID-19 transmission for disaster-affected people.

description.narrative: Yemen remains as the worst humanitarian crisis in the world according to international organizations including the UN. Most recent figures indicate a current estimate of 24.3 million people in need across the country, a slight increase from last year’s figure1, noting that the total population of Yemen is estimated at 30.5 million. This is mainly due to the prolonged and escalating armed conflict which has been accompanied in 2020 with natural disasters of heavy rains and floods in addition of the onset of COVID-19 in a country with collapsed health system and high rates of poverty, food insecurity and malnutrition.

title.narrative: DRA Babile Oromia and Moyale Somali Region Desert Locust Response

description.narrative:
Emergency Desert Locust  Response in Babile Woreda (Oromia) and Moyale woreda (Somali  Region). 

Key objective: people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets
Specific objective: addressing the most urgent needs of 27.395 desert locust affected people by providing MPC, emergency livelihood assistance and WASH support related to COVID-19.

Target group: A total of 27.395 individual beneficiaries (M:4931, W:6027, G:9040, B:7397) will be targeted.

Main activities:
- Distribution of specialized crop and grass seeds and farming tools, restocking of livestock for female-headed households and capacity building on DL control at the community level,

- Provision of MPC (Multi-Purpose Cash),

- Intervention to prevent the spread of COVID-19, such as distribution of Hygiene Kits, hygiene promotion and Installation/reparation of boreholes.
Expenditure 2020
Income to be recived from ETH 20143
NLD to ETH Recved fro ETH20143

title.narrative: Nigeria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: DRA funded NJR project with partners Tearfund, SCI, ICCO, and TdH. ZOA implements CASH component in Monguno LGA (in collaboration with ICCO partner JDPH), and WASH in Mafa LGA (in collaboration with SCI). In Mafa there is a small CASH component in collaboration with SCI.
1st Instalment received - NGA2001 (NJR)
Contract NGA2001 (NJR-COVID 19)
Contract NGA2001 (NJR2020)
Expenditure 2020
NJR2020 - 2nd Instalment receieved - SCI

title.narrative: ACC-R1 Participation

description.narrative: ACCR1 - ACC-R1 Participation

title.narrative: ACC-I1 - Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: Recruit community level staff from affected communities, conduct feedback meetings and post distribution monitoring among beneficiaries

comment.narrative: This comprises recruited hygiene promoters, community nutrition mobilizers, community committees, community leaders and participants of community engagement and feedback meetings. Hygiene promoters received training on conducting hygiene promotion and safety measures, especially during COVID. They all received training on PSEA, accountability to affected population and the ZOA's complaints and response mechanisms. WASHCOM members received training in repair and minor maintenance of hand pumps.

title.narrative: CHS-R1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: CHSR1 - CHS-R1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: CHS-I1 - Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: 8 months of multipurpose cash for 1630 individuals in Monguno LGA and 5 months of multipurpose cash for 1000 individuals in Mafa LGA

comment.narrative:
A total of 6,045 individuals received cash: 3,228 under NJR2019 top-up and 2,817 under the regular NJR2020 MPC.
Beneficiaries reached under NJR2019 top-up (Monguno): 3,228 individuals, 51.2% females were reached. Of this number, 2,359 received a monthly per capital transfer value of NGN6,940 over the period of six months. 2,171 individuals collected 6 tranches; 159 individuals collected 5 tranches; 6 individuals collected 4 tranches and 33 individuals collected 1 tranche totaling 2,359 individuals or 102.56% of the original project target of 2,300 individuals to receive 6 rounds of cash.
Due to underspend on vendors commission and other budget lines, ZOA provided one round of emergency multipurpose cash to 869 fire victims within the project location. The per capital transfer amount was NGN3,595. 2,359 individuals reached under the original target + 869 reached with one-time emergency cash gives a total of 3,228 individuals reached.
Beneficiaries reached under NJR2020 (Mafa/Monguno): 2,817 individuals received multipurpose cash in Monguno and Mafa under the regular NJR project. Of this number, Monguno accounts for 1,778 while Mafa accounts for 1,039 individuals referred by SCI for cash support. Cash collection rate in Mafa was 99.9% while that of Monguno was 99.7%. Due to delays by EFCC to issue cash clearance, the transfer in Monguno was short by two months, 6 instead of 8 rounds.

title.narrative: FSC-COV-R3 Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods

description.narrative: COVR3 - COV-FSC-R3 Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods

title.narrative: FSC-COV-I3 - Number of people receiving COVID-19 related assistance (FS&L)

description.narrative: Cash provided to individuals with protection concerns for food

comment.narrative:
Four protection organizations referred 295 households with protection concerns for cash support. These households contained 1,016 individuals. 98.5% of cash electronically transferred to these households was redeemed. The remaining 1.5% accounts for households that left the project areas before end of project as well as those excluded for varying reasons. For example, a household was referred twice by two protection organizations.
The protection organizations that ZOA worked with are: IRC and PUI (two international organizations) and GISCOR and HARAF (two national organizations)

title.narrative: LOC-I3 - Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

description.narrative: Conduct training for community volunteers, local staff and community leaders on project activities

comment.narrative: This comprises recruited hygiene promoters, community nutrition mobilizers, community committees, community leaders and participants of community engagement and feedback meetings. Hygiene promoters received training on conducting hygiene promotion and safety measures, especially during COVID. They all received training on PSEA, accountability to affected population and the ZOA's complaints and response mechanisms. title.narrative: WSH-R1 Hygiene promotion

description.narrative: WSHR1 - WSH-R1 Hygiene promotion

title.narrative: WSH-I1 - Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: 1,200 households benefit from both hygiene promotion and soap for laundry and bathing

comment.narrative: 1,196 households/families or 8262 individuals (137.7% of target) have benefitted from the distribution of soaps to meet up with daily basic hygiene needs. The soaps include 3 pieces of laundry soaps (200g) and 13 pieces of bathing soaps (250g). The number of beneficiaries reported represents the actual household membership reached.

title.narrative: WSH-R2 Excreta Disposal

description.narrative: WSHR2 - WSH-R2 Excreta Disposal

title.narrative: WSH-I2 - Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Construction and rehabilitation of 95 stances of latrines and 50 units of bathing shelters

comment.narrative: Additional 20 stances were constructed to the initially constructed 95 stances across 3 of the 5 communities (Zannari, Simari and Mala Kyariri); making a total of 115 stances of latrines. This was because there were still needs and the budget allowed ZOA to fill the gaps by constructing additional stances of latrines and bathing shelters. Additionally, 18 stances of bathing shelters were constructed across 3 of the 5 communities where the needs persisted. These additional latrines and bathing shelters were constructed as stand-alone (a block of one) and were all gender segregated and marked. ZOA worked with the communities in selecting the locations for latrines and bathing shelters and in identifying areas with the most needs.

title.narrative: WSH-R3 Drainage

description.narrative: WSHR3 - WSH-R3 Drainage

title.narrative: WSH-I3 - Number of people living in settlements with a functional drainage network

description.narrative: Cleaning of drainages within residential areas of targeted beneficiaries

comment.narrative: The drainage cleaning equipment were distributed across all 5 communities. Equipment include; Diggers (50), Wheel barrows (25), Shovels (50), Hand gloves (50), Gum boots (50), Metallic rakes (10) and Water pump set (1). Materials purchased were recommended by respective communities during feedback meetings. All equipment were left in the custody of the communities' respective leader's households and intending users collected these equipment, use them and refund them when they are done so other groups could also have access to the tools. This was also a suggestion from the community members during one of the feedback meetings as the equipment was not enough for distribution in smaller clusters. All 8262 individuals who received soap reside in these locations.

title.narrative: WSH-R4 Water Supply

description.narrative: WSHR4 - WSH-R4 Water Supply

title.narrative: WSH-I4 - Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Construction/rehabilitation of 2 solar boreholes to provide water access to affected population

comment.narrative: The 2 solar powered boreholes drilled in June were fully equipped and commissioned in July 2020 and one additional solar powered borehole was rehabilitated in Simari community bringing the total number of solar boreholes to 3 to benefit 9000 individuals. The borehole is equipped with 20 cubic meters overhead water tank with reticulation to 1 fetching point which has 10 tap heads. Due to existing water gaps and on the request of the community, ZOA repaired/rehabilitated 7 dysfunctional handpumps in Mala Kyariri and Simari communities to benefit 3,500 individuals

title.narrative: WSH-R6 Hygiene promotion (Awareness)

description.narrative: WSHR6 - WSH-R6 Hygiene promotion (Awareness)

title.narrative: WSH-I6 - Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promoters conduct hygiene promotion activities in project communities

comment.narrative: 9 additional hygiene promoters (5 males and 4 females) were recruited locally to add to the existing 16 hygiene promoters; making a total of 25 hygiene promoters (10 males and 15 females). This was done to increase the reach of hygiene promotion and COVID - 19 awareness messages. Beneficiaries were reached through door to door visits only as per recommended by the WaSH sector due to the COVID - 19. All hygiene promoters were equipped with nose masks and hand sanitizers and maintained social distance during sensitization sessions. The increase in household membership benefiting from hygiene promotion was due to the existence of households with larger membership as well as the willingness of other households to participate in hygiene promotion sessions.

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020 (Lead Agency): Dutch Relief Alliance - NGOs Joint Humanitarian Response to the Syria Crisis

description.narrative: Overall goal SJR2020: Improved wellbeing of conflict-affected people inside Syria, especially the most vulnerable. Interventions will be done in the areas of Food Security and Livelihoods, Health, Individual household shelter, Protection and Multi-Purpose Cash.

SJR2020 will focus on Syria, targeting the most vulnerable households. Within Syria the choice has been made to concentrate on Aleppo and Rural Damascus. It is anticipated that SJR2020 will reach around 111.533 beneficiaries

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 4130 7320 AC Apeldoorn The Netherlands

sector.narrative: Health, NFIs and Shelter, WASH, Multi-purpose cash

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative:
The project will rehabilitate domestic shelter for vulnerable families in Aleppo, including household adaptations for people living with mobility impairment. This activity is carried out by ZOAs partner Medair.

In Aleppo and Rural Damascus, ZOA will work with GOPA-DERD to identify most vulnerable families for vocational training in subjects likely to provide a future income for the households. Participants will also receive lifeskills training, and cash for attendance while undergoing the training. 

The activities are closely coordinated with other SJR partners, to facilitate referrals of beneficiaries, and joint learning.

Covid-19: The Covid-19 project aims to provide essential water, sanitation and personal hygiene goods and services for preparedness and prevention of COVID-19 to 9, 000 vulnerable individuals in Nashabiyeh (Duma, Rural Damascus). The main project activities are: -distribution of hygiene kits -installation of household water tanks -communication of critical risk information. CHS: The overall expected result by the end of 2020 is that ZOA Syria Response and its local partners operate more in line with the ZOA standard ‘Way of Working’, thereby strengthening adherence also to the Core Humanitarian Standards. Funding is within the SJR fund, a budget of 22,000 EUR has been allocated to accountability/CHS. Project Objectives are: 1. Strengthened accountability for affected populations 2. ZOA Management team is equipped to lead and manage staff 3. ZOA programmes are conflict sensitive 4. ZOA has more and better equipped local partners

title.narrative: Increase member involvement through the association activities to increase revenue and membership base

description.narrative: 2019 PlanPlanned activities include My.Coop Aggregation training Youth workshop FM coaching development of extension strategy2020 PlanExchange Business visit to PDFA Advanced Record Keeping (Might be skipped due to Covid Financial management training Governance training and Youth council masterclass and development of extension strategy for 2020

The mian objcetive of CDFA is to diversify their income sources and increasing their capital base and reducing on donor dependency. The association also realizes the need to increase its membership base and involving youths and women as it has an impact on their revenue. However the association sees the need to provide more member services to its members as a way of proving its relevance need for members to affiliate. BHAG 2021: A financially self-sustaining organisation providing quality services to 4 750 members towards a profitable agribusiness by focusing on improved crop production promoting mixed-farming and improved marketing. Objectives: Increasing membership to 4750 and becoming a financially self sustaining organisation

The project will focus on increasing revenue for the association through member involvement and provision of extension services. It will also tackle the issue of youth and gender inclusiveness to help youth participation in the development of the district through the association. They will be coaching in financial management to help the organisation put internal controls and assess the business's potentil to grow.

title.narrative: Down to Zero: Building Back Better in times of Covid-19

description.narrative: The programme will build and expand on the Alliance’s collective achievements to date, scaling up the 2016-2020 Down to Zero (DtZ) programme and being complementary to the 2020-2021 Voice for Change (VfC) programme. This will allow the Alliance and its partners to effectively address SEC in the rapidly evolving context during and after the Covid-19 pandemic.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs the Netherlands

title.narrative: Joining Forces for Africa (JOFA)

description.narrative: This action has been designed to respond rapidly to the global COVID-19 pandemic emergency. It seeks to address the most marginalised vulnerable population in the 5 target African countries: Ethiopia, Kenya, Mali, Senegal and Uganda.Children are the hidden victims, facing threats to their wellbeing and protection as a result of the increased risks of violence and abuse. Infection prevention control measures that national governments have taken to limit the spread of the disease have a direct impact on the lives of children and their increased exposure to violence. The proposed action seeks to address the immediate protection needs of children

title.narrative: BBB Bangladesh : Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 Bangladesh

description.narrative: The Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated the already complex web of vulnerabilities of children who are victims of, or at risk of SEC  and poses unprecedented threats to their protection. The projectś goal is to make sure children and youth are better protected when at risk or victim of sexual exploitation, during and in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic. This will be achieved through the projects 5 outcomes. This project is under the programme DtZ Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 that will build on the 2016-2020 DtZ and complement the 2020-2021 Voice for Change.

title.narrative: Strengthening the health system to maintain access to quality care in the context of COVID-19

description.narrative: To support the Ministry of Health to face the COVID-19 pandemic, this project aims to intervene in 260 health structures in the 6 districts of Boucle du Mouhoun, to strengthen the prevention and management of COVID-19, access of the most vulnerable populations to primary health care and access to better hygiene and sanitation. Objectives: 1- Capacity building of health structures 2- Improving access to water and hygiene 3-Support CSPS through HR, medical and logistical equipment 4- Strengthen the capacities of health workers in psychological first aid, treatment of GBV and PSS to health workers. Contract start date is 01-08-2020, but ECHO has agreed that we can start on 01-09-2020.
Expenditure 2020

title.narrative: BF Burkina Faso Joint Response 2019

description.narrative: Since early 2019, non-state armed groups have consolidated their presence in especially the Northern part of Burkina Faso. There has been a sharp increase in violence which has unfolded a dramatic humanitarian crisis. Currently, Tdh responds through an Acute Joint Response in the Titao district, with service provision including in primary health care, natal care, GBV treatment, child protection, PSS. Project funded by the Dutch MFA, with Plan as lead organisation. Project includes a COVID-19 Top Up.

Training conducted for 68 Health workers drawn from Matayos and Teso North sub-counties. Key action points included : Consulting with NGAO and secure platform for community sensitisation on issues related to Covid-19. Facts - spread, prevention, treatment and management. Supporting the police and gender desk to adequately provide victims/survivors with P3 form ( facilitate printing/ or monthly deliver printed copies P3 forms) - Implementing partners in Busia
Government social welfare workforce training was planned for but was postponed due to unavoidable circumstances from the facilitators ( Dept of Children Services staff). The training is planned for Feb/ 2021.;

comment.narrative: The former DCC proposed refurbishment of former police canteen to be used as a CPU. This proposal has been disputed by the current DCC. He has categorically stated that a CPU should only be established at the police station. This will ease deployment and sustainability. Consultations are still underway with the County Commissioner and OCPD Teso North on commitment and provision of alternative site for the CPU. In regards to the Isolation center, the medical officer has proposed a facelift of the maternity wing as the padeatric wing ( Isolation is brand new) and might require minimal actions.;

title.narrative: # of advocacy activities conducted aimed at influencing the increase of government budget allocation for children needs

description.narrative: # of advocacy activities conducted aimed at influencing the increase of government budget allocation for children needs

comment.narrative:
3 advocacy activities were conducted. The Busia County CSOs analysed the CIPD 2018-2021, County Budget Review and Outlook Paper (CBROP)2020/MTEF 2021/2022-2023/2024 & CFSP for FY 2021 - 2022 , Engaged with the MCA and County Authority, CSOs subsequently submission of a memorandum to the County assembly for petitioning for increased budget allocation for children's needs.
Here is the link to the County website https://busiacounty.go.ke/main/index.php/downloads/category/6-county-budget-documents Under expenditure due to planned consultant fee for engagement of cec that was not utilized hence savings. The savings will be used to host a breakfast meeting between the County Children Assembly members and contribution towards development of Children Policy;

The activity was delayed because the development of initial evidence brief and advocacy messages was dependent on the results of the Needs Assessment and Baseline report, The activity will be conducted between February and March, 2021 with reference to the Needs Assessment and baseline report.;

comment.narrative:
201 ( (94M & 107F) community members participated in community dialogues. The structured community dialogues were facilitated by different experts : Health, Gender and Children departments under the leadership of the Deputy County Commissioners & Senior Chiefs (NGAO) The aim of the dialogue was to sensitise the community members on VAC - identification, prevention and response; on the available referral pathways. In addition, the impact of Covid-19 (SGBV, child exploitation, child labour
Under expenditure was due to the fact that radio talk show were not undertaken hence no cost incurred The savings will be used to support countywide radio talk-show with a special focus on SGBV and teenage pregnancies;

Approximately 125,000 communities/public reached through 3 local radio stations: Nyota FM, Bulala FM & Emuria FM in partnership with CRS - MWENDO implementing partners. Discussions were conducted in Kiswahili and local dialect. 84 participants reached during dissemination of the EVAC 2020-2024 strategic plan conducted at County and at the sub counties level. 155 members participated in community dialogues held in two locations ( Nangoma and Kocholia,
Under expenditure as less was spent on community dilogues and IEC materials are yet to be procure. Ban;
The activity is planned for Q4 2021 hence no expenses reported.;

comment.narrative: 16 Days of Gender activism was planned for, however, the department of children services, mandated to mobilise children for the planned activity had an overlapping activity, organised from the national office. The budget spend relates to child webinars as Smart phones budget for were not procured.;

The initial budget allocated for children's airtime was reduced by half. This allowed us to support additional 8 children from Mombasa and Marsabit Counties. Furthermore, Mtoto News used the same platform to facilitate participation of additional 7 children from Kitui, Nairobi, Machakos, Kwale and Narok Counties. This activity was implemented during the reporting period . The expenses will reflect in the next Quarter.;

title.narrative: Improving reporting and response of CSEC cases during COVID-19 through the national Child Helpline -116

description.narrative: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‑19) pandemic is exacting a huge toll on children, families, communities, and societies across the world, thus TdH-NL will support the costs of engaging (5) counselors to increase the human resource capacity of the Helpline 116
Expenditure 2020

title.narrative: Children Immediately safeguarded (provided counselling, rescue and referrals)

description.narrative: Children Immediately safeguarded (provided counselling, rescue and referrals)

title.narrative: # of boys immediately safeguarded

description.narrative: # of boys immediately safeguarded

comment.narrative: A total of 14,024 boys were safeguarded. Out of the total; 5318 boys went through counselling for Child abuse, reproductive health, relationships, Self-esteem and Identity issues. 92of there cases were of child abuse. 8706 were cases of information inquiry on 116 services and child rights issues. 1483 cases were referred to the Children office, Chief’s office, Kenya Police and Court. Childline’s case management team is following up these cases with the different service providers and the clients to ensure delivery of quality service. The target was not reached, the Call Centre experienced internet downtime which affected the number of calls received. There was an over expenditure on budget because costs for girls immediately safeguarded was reported under this activity.;

A total of 3,751 boys were safeguarded. Out of the total; 2,494 boys went through counselling issues like abuse(Physical, Neglect and Abandonment), reproductive health, et cetera. 1,257 were referred to the Children office, Chief’s office, Kenya Police, Court, and CSO's like red cross and MSF for support. Childline’s case management team is following up these cases with the different service providers and the clients to ensure delivery of quality service. No children were rescued during this period. The target was not reached because the contract with the donor was signed late. However, plans have been made to meet the target in the subsequent months. There is an under expenditure because project staff salary for the month of July was not paid due to delay in signing of the contract;

title.narrative: # of girls immediately safeguarded

description.narrative: # of girls immediately safeguarded

comment.narrative: A total of 15165 girls were safeguarded. Out of the total; 6028 went through counselling on various child protection issues like abuse (Sexual abuse, child marriage, physical abuse), relationships, reproductive health among others. 2586 were referred for other services to children offices, Kenya police, Hospitals, chief’s office for support. Childline’s case management team is following up these cases with the different service providers and the clients to ensure delivery of quality service. No children were rescued during this period. The target was not reached, Call Centre experienced internet down time which affected the number of calls received. There was an under expenditure on the activity because some cost for the activity were reported on number of boys safeguarded.;

A total of 4195 girls were safeguarded during the reporting period. Out of the total reached, 2567 girls went through counselling on various child protection issues like abuse(Sexual abuse, child marriage, physical abuse), child-parent relationship, boy-girl relationships, reproductive health among others. 1,628 were referred for other services to children offices, Kenya police, Hospitals, chief’s office and other partners for support. All the cases are being followed up by Childline’s case management team. No children were rescued during this period. The target was not reached because the contract with the donor was signed late. However, plans have been made to meet the target in the subsequent months. There is an under expenditure which was brought by delay in signing of the contract.;

title.narrative: " Community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities - Using media (social media, radio, TV) to target parents and caregivers "

description.narrative: " Community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities - Using media (social media, radio, TV) to target parents and caregivers "

title.narrative: # of community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities

description.narrative: # of community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities

comment.narrative: The Covid- 19 awareness messages were shared through Childline’s social media pages i.e. Facebook and Twitter where 1371 people were reached. The target was not met because, peer educators delayed in giving feedback on the messages before they could be used. Since more children will be engaged in October 2020, they will be able to interact with the awareness messages and provide feedback. To meet the target, daily posting of the messages on social media and frequent boosting will be done. The messages will also be shared through TV and Radio stations. The funds allocated to this activity were never used because only few messages had been shared. With the frequent boosting of the social media messages and airing via mass media in the coming month the budget will be utilized.;

The Covid- 19 awareness messages were shared through Childline’s social media pages i.e. Facebook and Twitter where 60430 people were reached. In addition to this 763000 people were reached via KTN News TV and Ramogi FM. The target was overachieved because the radio stations have a big coverage hence more people were reached. There was also frequent boosting on the social media which contributed to more people being reached. There was an expenditure on this activity because the budget for the previous quarter was utilized to boost the content online.;

title.narrative: WATCH 24/7 Kenya : Working together for child online protection in Kenya

description.narrative: The need for this project is born out of experience in implementing interventions against OCSE in Kenya, which has witnessed an increase in online child sexual exploitation. The proposed intervention comes at a time when a lot of online learning is taking place due to closure of schools as a result of Covid-19.

title.narrative: Nigeria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: Second year that Tdh responds to the Nigerian crisis within the Nigeria Joint Response, funded by the Dutch MFA, and led by Save the Children. Location: Borno State (Mafa, Dikwa and Gwoza LGA) Activities include WASH, natal education, cholera/ malaria/ measles awareness, community based management of childhood illnesses - through mobile teams, PSS, CPiE awareness and CM. Project includes a COVID-19 Top Up and Innovation scale-up funding.

title.narrative: BBB Nepal:Down to Zero - Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 (DtZ-BBB)

description.narrative: With a close collaboration with Government, law enforcement agencies and private sector actors in Nepal, this project will be able to address the issue of SEC in a holistic manner incorporating the feedback and experiences of all stakeholders. The first hand information from the field will be applied by informing and addressing a wide range of stakeholders from several levels of government and LEA including the communities, CBOs, students and survivors. All of them coming together to address the issues of human trafficking and SEC within a time of urgent and ever changing response is needed.

participating-org.narrative: WYSHER (Women Youth Empowerment in Social Service and Human Rights)

title.narrative: Philippines: DtZ Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 in Cebu Province

description.narrative: The Building Back Better of Down-to-Zero Project for 2021 is focused on continuing existing services for the protection and prevention of Online Sexual Exploitation of Children (OSEC) and Sexual Exploitation of Children in Travel and Tourism (SECTT) in Cebu Province with the integration of recovery and rehabilitation amidst the COVID-19 pandemic situation. This project aims that children and youth are better protected when at risk or victim of sexual exploitation, during and in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: For the sixth year, Tdh is part of the Syria Joint Response, funded by the Dutch MFA, and led by ZOA. Tdh is mostly providing assistance to people with disabilities in Jaramana, Qattana, Daf El shok, Eastern Ghota (Rural Damascus) and Jeble (Aleppo). Activities: Food vouchers, MHPSS and physical rehab, fisiotherapy, or rehab. Project includes a COVID-19 Top Up.

title.narrative: BBB:Thailand: Building Back Better Project Thailand

description.narrative: Key strategy is to create a sustained response that especially takes into account the vulnerability that the Covid-19 emergency has created so children’s voice is amplified so that the full range of stakeholders are aware, mobilised and supported to promote protection systems. Due to the content of Covid-19 emergency especially increasing the vulnerability to OCSE, then the community level awareness and reporting systems will especially focus on OCSE feeding into reporting and the strengthening of CPS to enable sustained resilience.

Renforcement des capacités des établissements d'enseignement en santé et droits sexuels et reproductifs (SDSR) pour l'inclusion des jeunes au Bénin

description.narrative:
Le projet vise le renforcement des capacités d’institutions d'EFTP/ES et d’organisations partenaires au Bénin à consolider la formation SDSR axée sur les jeunes. Il s'inscrit dans le contexte des défis importants auxquels ceux-ci sont confrontés en matière de SDSR, notamment les grossesses précoces, les avortements à risques, les IST, combiné au déficit de compétences et d’accès aux travailleurs du secteur sanitaire et social. Avec une approche genre sensible aux besoins des jeunes, le projet visera la révision et l'intégration des programmes de formation SDSR, le renforcement des capacités d'enseignement et la mise en place d’une plateforme basée sur la recherche pour le dialogue et l'engagement politique. Les activités du projet favoriseront l'apprentissage croisé entre les organisations participantes afin d'autonomiser les professionnels SDSR pour renforcer leur efficacité collective pour l’inclusion des jeunes. Ceux-ci amélioreront ainsi leurs capacités à relever leurs défis de SDSR et pourront mieux réaliser leurs objectifs éducatifs et professionnels. L'impact de la Covid-19 nécessitera aussi l’intégration de l'apprentissage à distance. À long terme, le consortium localsera un mécanisme durable pour la mise à jour continues des programmes d'études SDSR, le renforcement des capacités de formation, la recherche appliquée et l'amélioration du dialogue intergénérationnel sur SDSR et l'inclusiondes jeunes.
​
OKP-ICP-BEN-104887
The proposed project must contribute to the following long-term impact: −Better information and greater freedom of choice for young people about their sexuality

L'Institut national d'ingénierie de formation et de renforcement des capacités de formateurs
L’Université Nationale des Sciences, Technologies, Ingénierie et Mathématiques
Rayon des Initiatives Culturelles Musicales et des Arts Oraux Association

Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

+

title.narrative: National Initiatives for Sust. & Climate-smart Oil Palm Smallholders (NI-SCOPS)

description.narrative:
The NI-SCOPS programme designed by Solidaridad, IDH, the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MoFA) and LNV, is a new mechanism to provide tangible support and to measurably contribute to climate and sustainable development goals in oil palm landscapes. By supporting local governments and other stakeholders to improve resilience, productivity and incomes of smallholders and workers, and at the same time protect and restore valuable natural resources, these landscapes contribute to SDGs and the Paris Agreement. It strengthens existing and builds new partnerships with national and subnational governments. NISCOPS complements and builds on existing (private sector driven) voluntary market initiatives. The initiatives have started in Indonesia, Malaysia, Ghana and Nigeria. The results of the NISCOPS programme in 2020 was shared with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MoFA) in the Donor Steering Group meeting on January 13, 2021. Following is a short summary.
In 2020, interventions were defined and a budget was presented for each respective country in the Inception Report. This gave the green light to commence the implementation of the programme, and despite the Covid-19 pandemic, results have been achieved.

OmiDelta Fonds Acteurs Non Etatiques pour la composante AEPHA

description.narrative:
Deux catégories d'organisations sont ciblées pour bénéficier des fonds ANE du Programme OmiDelta pour les projets AEPHA : • ONG et OSP nationales pour la mise en œuvre de projets de petite taille • ONG internationales ou ONG nationales de grande envergure pour la mise en œuvre de projets de grande taille
Les groupes cibles des projets AEPHA sont les populations pauvres et vulnérables qui n'ont pas accès à des services d’approvisionnement en Eau Potable, d'Hygiène et d'Assainissement (AEPHA) durables et de qualité améliorée.
En outre, le thème transversal de la gouvernance cible plus spécifiquement les organisations locales de la société civile qui veillent au Contrôle Citoyen de l'Action Publique (CCAP), soutiennent les pratiques de la reddition de comptes par les élus locaux, et encouragent le renforcement des capacités afin de renforcer la gouvernance dans le secteur. Le Fonds ANE se concentrera également sur la promotion de l’égalité genre et de la jeunesse par la mise en place de stratégies de création d’opportunités d’emplois, de conditions de travail et d’initiative de renforcement des capacités favorables aux femmes et aux jeunes dans le secteur.

L'objectif général de OmiDelta Fonds ANE est de contribuer à ce que « Les populations pauvres et vulnérables vivant dans les zones couvertes par OmiDelta Fonds ANE aient un accès équitable, utilisent les services AEPHA durables et jouissent de la mise en œuvre de la GIRE ».
L’objectif spécifique de AEPHA est "Accroissement de l'accès et de l'utilisation des services AEPHA durables par les populations pauvres et vulnérables". L’impact global visé par les projets AEPHA de OmiDelta Fonds ANE est : • Au moins 140.000 femmes, hommes et enfants ont accès aux services d’eau durable et de qualité • Au moins 340.000 femmes, hommes et enfants ont accès aux services d’hygiène et d’assainissement améliorés

L'étude permettant de faire l'état de la situation au début du projet est réalisée en novembre et décembre 2018. Cette étude a concerné les indicateurs des 3 outcomes clés à renseigner par la SNV à savoir : • Nombre de personnes (h/f) ayant accès et qui utilisent des services d’alimentation en eau potable (urbain/rural) • Nombre de personnes (f/h) ayant accès et qui utilisent les services d’hygiène et d’assainissement (urbain/rural) • Nombre de personnes (f/h) qui adoptent les bonnes pratiques en matière d’hygiène et assainissement (urbain/rural)
Le rapport de l'étude est téléchargé sur cette page.

La durabilité des projets AEPHA s’apprécie sous plusieurs angles à savoir : la durabilité financière, la durabilité institutionnelle, la durabilité environnementale, la durabilité technique, la durabilité sociale (FIETS). Les interventions du programme doivent assurer un effet qui perdure pendant au moins 15 ans à compter du démarrage du programme. Pour cela, le programme développera des stratégies pour responsabiliser les acteurs dans ce sens. Les activités qui seront mise en œuvre incluent un appui au cadre politique et stratégique pour le développement des mécanismes qui assurent la pérennisation des acquis.

Le Fonds Acteurs Non Etatiques (Fonds ANE) est un des instruments de OmiDelta, le nouveau programme d’eau et assainissement proposé par l'Ambassade du Royaume des Pays-Bas (APB) en réponse à la volonté du Gouvernement béninois de réaliser l'objectif 6 de développement durable « Assurer la disponibilité et la gestion durable de l’eau et de l’assainissement pour tous » et ses 8 cibles. Le programme OmiDelta prévoit de développer 3 instruments à savoir : un guichet d’appui gouvernemental, une structure d'assistance technique et un Fonds d’appui aux acteurs non étatiques.
La gestion du Fonds ANE est confiée à l’Organisation Néerlandaise de Développement (SNV) et couvrira une période de 4,5 ans du 1er décembre 2016 au 30 juin 2021. Le Fonds vise à financer les Organisations Non Gouvernementales (ONG), les Organisations de la Société Civile (OSC) et les Organisations du Secteur Privé (OSP) pour la mise en œuvre de projets et initiatives ayant pour objectif (i) d’améliorer l’accès, l’utilisation, la qualité et la durabilité des services d’Approvisionnement en Eau Potable, Hygiène et Assainissement (AEPHA) et (ii) d’opérationnaliser la Gestion Intégrée des Ressources en Eau (GIRE) au Bénin au travers d’actions concrètes.
Le Fonds prévoit également le développement de thèmes transversaux notamment la gouvernance, le genre, l’emploi des jeunes et le changement climatique comme partie intégrante aux projets qui seront financés.
En tant que gestionnaire du Fonds, la SNV supervisera l'ensemble du processus de gestion des projets afin d'assurer la pertinence, un bon rapport qualité-prix et une bonne qualité de mise en œuvre des projets. Les responsabilités de la SNV comprennent, entre autres, la sélection des projets et des organisations exécutantes, le suivi et l'évaluation du processus de mise en œuvre, et la fourniture d'un soutien administratif, financier et technique si nécessaire.

L’APB à Cotonou a commencé à appuyer le secteur de l’eau du Bénin depuis 2004. Divers programmes tels que EAU I, EAU II et EAU III, 9 AEV, PPPLM, et NPT ProfEau ont été mis en œuvre. Ils visaient, notamment à expérimenter dans le secteur de l’eau l’approche sectorielle, la décentralisation / déconcentration et l’alignement sur les procédures nationales pour assurer une meilleure appropriation et durabilité des résultats. De 2007-2012, le Programme Pluriannuel d’appui au secteur Eau et Assainissement (PPEAI) suivit de PPEAII (2013) visaient la transition vers un appui budgétaire sectoriel et une approche sectorielle dans les secteurs de l’accès à l’eau potable, l’assainissement, l’hygiène et la gestion des ressources en eau. Enfin, le Fonds de Transition d’Eau de 2016-2017, suivi du Programme d’Eau prévu de 2017 à 2021 ont rétabli la collaboration bilatérale entre le Bénin et les Pays-Bas afin de satisfaire les besoins pressants du secteur. La formulation du Programme d’Eau dont fait partie OmiDelta intervient à un moment où les stratégies d’approvisionnement en eau potable au Bénin sont en pleine actualisation. Il en est de même pour le document de stratégie de croissance pour la réduction de la pauvreté et celle de la promotion de l’hygiène et de l’assainissement de base en faisant de l’Assainissement Total Piloté par les Communautés (ATPC) la méthode phare d’intervention en milieu rural. De plus, les documents de politique et stratégies sur le genre, la décentralisation et l’intégration des jeunes dans le secteur de l’eau et de l’assainissement font partie des préoccupations phares de ce programme.
OmiDelta Programme WASH Non-State Actors Fund

Les institutions sont en mesure de s'acquitter de leurs obligations en matière d'eau potable et d'assainissement

description.narrative: Ce résultat correspond à l'output de EKN "Institutions are able to carry out their functions with respect to drinking water and sanitation". Excepté l'indicateur de EKN lié à la durabilité, les 2 autres indicateurs ne sont pas renseignés par la SNV sur la page du Fonds ANE pour la composante AEPHA mais sont renseignés directement sur les pages individuelles des projets.

title.narrative: Nombre de projets utilisant les outils de durabilité (clause, contrôle, pactes)

description.narrative: Cet indicateur correspond au libellé anglais de EKN "Does this project use the DGIS-IGG sustainability tools (clause, check, compact)". Il est à renseigner par la SNV, il s'agit pour les 7 projets AEPHA financés par le Fonds ANE d'assurer la mise en oeuvre de la durabilité dans leurs projets.

comment.narrative: L’ensemble des 7 projets financés par le Fonds ANE ont une clause de durabilité dans leur contrat.

24-02-2021: Les 7 projets AEPHA travaillent en continue à la prise en compte des outils de durabilité selon le concept FIETS et en particulier : - Renforcement des structures locales existantes - Valorisation des savoirs endogènes pour la conception des modèles d’ouvrages / équipements HA - Analyse et mise en œuvre des interventions par rapport aux 5 dimensions FIETS de la durabilité aboutissant à la signature de pactes de durabilité

26-02-2020: Les 7 projets AEPHA travaillent en continue à la prise en compte des outils de durabilité selon le concept FIETS et en particulier : - Renforcement des structures locales existantes - Valorisation des savoirs endogènes pour la conception des modèles d’ouvrages / équipements HA - Analyse et mise en œuvre des interventions par rapport aux 5 dimensions FIETS de la durabilité aboutissant à la signature de pactes de durabilité

L’ensemble des 7 projets financés par le Fonds ANE ont une clause de durabilité dans leur contrat mais des pactes de durabilité entre les projets et les communes, les usagers, les prestataires et les services techniques pourraient être signés.

title.narrative: Degré d'intégration du genre et de l'inclusion sociale, de la durabilité, du changement climatique et de la biodiversité au sein de l’ensemble des phases du Programme OmiDelta Fonds ANE

description.narrative:
Cet outcome a été formulé afin de renseigner le résultat de DGIS / EKN " Results area 1: General Priorities". Les priorités générales correspondent à 4 thèmes transversaux capitaux de la stratégie néerlandaise de coopération au développement qui ont été évalués au niveau de chaque projet des deux composantes. Ils sont ainsi traduits en français :
1. Inclusion (genre, sociale, économique, etc.) 2. Adaptation et résilience au changement climatique 3. Impact à long terme et durable (durabilité systémique) 4. Écosystèmes, biodiversité et impact environnemental
Pour rapporter sur ces priorités générales, il s’agit d’évaluer pour chaque thème s’il est suffisamment intégré et exécuté dans toutes les phases du programme (échelle de 1 à 5 : 1 étant complètement absent et 5 étant complètement intégré et exécuté dans toutes les phases du programme). Les phases qui seront évaluées par la SNV sont :
- Démarrage (y inclus « analysis, plan ») - Mise en œuvre - Suivi et évaluation (« monitoring, evaluation ») - Clôture (y inclus « learning »)
​

title.narrative: Progrès dans l’intégration de mesures permettant la durabilité systémique au sein des phases du Programme OmiDelta Fonds ANE

description.narrative: Cet indicateur permet de renseigner la priorité « Durable, long term impact (systemic sustainability) » de EKN sur une échelle de 1 à 5.

comment.narrative: En fin 2020, 4 projets AEPHA de petite taille et 1 projet de grande taille auront signé leurs pactes de durabilité. Cet indicateur aura presque atteint sa valeur cible escomptée.

24-02-2021: Les 8 projets AEPHA financés ont pris en compte de façon systémique les 5 dimensions de la durabilité (FIETS) lors de l’élaboration des propositions complètes et se sont attelés à les opérationnaliser au cours de la mise en œuvre des projets. L’après-projet sera consacré à la mise en œuvre d’un pacte de durabilité par les principales parties prenantes.

26-02-2020: Les 7 projets AEPHA financés ont pris en compte de façon systémique les 5 dimensions de la durabilité (FIETS) lors de l’élaboration des propositions complètes se sont attelés à les opérationnaliser au cours de la mise en œuvre des projets. L’après-projet sera consacré à la mise en œuvre d’un pacte de durabilité par les principales parties prenantes.

title.narrative: Progrès dans l’intégration de mesures favorisant les écosystèmes, la biodiversité et l'impact environnemental au sein des phases du Programme OmiDelta Fonds ANE AEPHA

description.narrative: Cet indicateur permet de renseigner la priorité « Ecosystems, biodiversity and environmental impact » de EKN sur une échelle de 1 à 5.

comment.narrative: En fin 2020, tous les projets seraient presque à terme et l’indicateur aura atteint sa valeur cible escomptée.

24-02-2021: Les 8 projets AEPHA financés ont pris en compte et l'impact environnemental aussi bien lors de l’élaboration des propositions complètes que de la mise en œuvre des projets. Toute construction d’ouvrages AEPHA d’envergure a été précédée de la réalisation d’EIES. En fin 2020, les 3 derniers projets AEPHA de petite taille et les 2 projets Covid sont entièrement clôturés, mais les 3 projets de grande taille le seront en 2021 donc le score de 5 ne pourrait être atteint qu'en 2021, après évaluation.

26-02-2020: Les 7 projets AEPHA financés ont pris en compte et l'impact environnemental aussi bien lors de l’élaboration des propositions complètes que de la mise en œuvre des projets. Toute les constructions d’ouvrages AEPHA d’envergure ont été précédées de la réalisation d’EIES.

title.narrative: Environnement favorable à l’atteinte des objectifs de développement durable amélioré

description.narrative:
Cet outcome a été formulé afin de renseigner le résultat de EKN « Results area 4: Enabling environment ».
Pour renseigner les résultats qui contribuent à un environnement favorable amélioré, EKN a formulé 10 thèmes « topics » clés non exhaustif :
- Renforcement des capacités (organisations ou individus) - Plaidoyer / lobbying auprès des gouvernements - Conseils politiques - Finance - Éducation / connaissances / recherche - Entrepreneuriat - Inclusion sociale - Durabilité - Climat et environnement - Innovation et technologie
Pour chacun des thèmes applicables, une évaluation qualitative des progrès est formulée et un nombre peut être ajouté au sein du narratif qualitatif pour l’appuyer et l’illustrer.

title.narrative: Niveau de prise en compte du climat et de l’environnement amélioré

description.narrative: Cet indicateur permet de renseigner le thème « Climate & Environment » de EKN.

comment.narrative: C'est un indicateur qualitatif. On vise une amélioration par rapport à l'année précédente.
C'est un indicateur qualitatif. On vise une amélioration par rapport à l'année précédente.

24-02-2021: En 2020, afin d'améliorer le niveau de prise en compte du climat et de l'environnement, plusieurs activités ont été menées : - Les projets AEPHA accordent une attention particulière à la préservation de l’environnement dans la mise en œuvre de leurs activités. - Des EIES sont réalisées avant toute construction d’ouvrage AEPHA de grande envergure. Les groupes cibles étaient : les Mairies (élus et agents communaux) et les communautés à la base.
C'est un indicateur qualitatif. On vise une amélioration par rapport à l'année précédente.

actual.value:
Les projets AEPHA accordent une attention particulière à la préservation de l’environnement dans la mise en œuvre de leurs activités. Les projets AEPHA de grande taille procèdent à une EIES préalable avant toute construction d’infrastructure AEPHA d’envergure.
Groupes cibles : - Mairies (élus et agents communaux) - Communautés à la base

comment.narrative: C'est un indicateur qualitatif. On vise une amélioration par rapport à l'année précédente.

24-02-2021: Les 8 projets AEPHA ont chacun mis en œuvre des activités de renforcement de capacités des membres des organisations actives dans le secteur à travers des sessions de formation sur divers thèmes : passation des marchés publics, influencing/plaidoyer, gestion des ouvrages AEPHA, CCC, marketing social, gestion des boues de vidange gestes barrières contre la propagation du Covid-19, etc. 7.364 personnes ont été formées dont 6.013 femmes (2.970 < 35 ans ; 3.043 > 35 ans) et 1.351 hommes (820 < 35 ans ; 531 > 35 ans). actual.value:

24-02-2021: Les 3 projets AEPHA de grande taille travaillent pour le développement de l’entreprenariat local. Helvetas a notamment promu 27 micro-entrepreneurs dans le domaine du sanimarketing des produits et services HA. Des initiatives des PPP sont établies entre ces micro-entrepreneurs certains opérateurs privés (création d’espaces sanimarket) et les Communes. 260 groupements et groupes d’épargnes ont été renforcés et au moins 4.526 entrepreneurs appuyés dont au moins 4.495 femmes des groupes d’épargnes (2608 < 35 ans ; 1887 > 35 ans) et 31 hommes (19 < 35 ans ; 12 > 35 ans). Les groupes ibles étaient : les maçons, entrepreneurs, artisan-réparateurs, techniciens spécialistes, groupes d’épargnes et les autres opérateurs privés.
C'est un indicateur qualitatif. On vise une amélioration par rapport à l'année précédente.

actual.value: Les projets AEPHA de grande taille travaillent pour le développement de l’entreprenariat. Helvetas a notamment promu une des micro-entrepreneurs dans le domaine du sanimarketing des produits et services HA. Des initiatives pour la préfiguration de PPP sont établies entre ces micro-entrepreneurs et les Communes. Au moins 1.240 entrepreneurs appuyés dont au moins 1.061 femmes et 39 jeunes hommes. Groupes cibles : - Maçons - Entrepreneurs - Artisan-réparateurs - Techniciens spécialistes - Autres opérateurs privés

title.narrative: Utilisation par les populations de services d’eau potable de qualité améliorée

description.narrative: Cet outcome contribue au résultat de DGIS / EKN "Number of people with safely managed drinking water (SDG 6.1.1)". Cet outcome contribue au résultat clé et impact global de la composante AEPHA, à savoir "Au moins 140.000 femmes, hommes et enfants ont accès aux services d’eau durable et de qualité." De ces 140.000 personnes, au moins 72.800 sont des femmes ; et par milieu rural : 44.000 personnes sont ciblées dont 22.880 femmes ; et urbain : 96.000 sont ciblées dont 49.920 femmes. Plusieurs indicateurs du Fonds ANE permettent d'atteindre cette cible.

title.narrative: 1a. Nombre de personnes (h/f) utilisant des services d’alimentation en eau potable gérés en toute sécurité (urbain / rural)

description.narrative: Cet indicateur du Fonds ANE correspond exactement au libellé anglais de DGIS / EKN "Number of people using safely managed drinking water services (SDG 6.1.1)". Concernant les niveaux de services, le Fonds ANE respecte les niveaux de services du Programme commun OMS/UNICEF de suivi de l’approvisionnement en eau, de l’assainissement et d’hygiène (JMP). Suivant ces niveaux, le service "optimal / géré en toute sécurité" correspond à un "point d’eau amélioré situé à domicile (branchement particulier)" tel un robinet, qui doit donc être situé à moins de 15 minutes aller-retour et l'eau doit être disponible tout au long de l'année. Au vu des critères du JMP, les ouvrages que nous réalisons (PEA, FPM, Kiosques) ne sont pas des points d’eau améliorés à domicile, nous ne pouvons donc pas renseigner cet indicateur.

comment.narrative: Cet indicateur mesurant le progrès, aucune personne n’a bénéficié d’une amélioration des conditions d’accès à l’eau potable à l’étape de l’étude de référence. Toutefois l’état de la situation actuelle par niveau de services est renseigné dans le Rapport annuel 2018.
Au vu des critères du JMP, les ouvrages que nous réalisons (PEA, FPM, Kiosques) ne sont pas des points d’eau améliorés à domicile, nous ne pouvons donc pas renseigner cet indicateur.

24-02-2021: Au vu des critères du JMP, les ouvrages que nous réalisons (PEA, FPM, kiosques) ne sont pas des points d’eau améliorés à domicile, nous ne pouvons donc pas renseigner cet indicateur. | 24-02-2021: Au vu des critères du JMP, les ouvrages que nous réalisons (PEA, FPM, Kiosques) ne sont pas des points d’eau améliorés à domicile, nous ne pouvons donc pas renseigner cet indicateur.

title.narrative: 1b. Nombre de personnes (h/f) utilisant des services d’alimentation en eau potable basique (urbain/rural)

description.narrative: Cet indicateur du Fonds ANE, peut aussi permettre de renseigner l'indicateur de DGIS / EKN "Number of people using safely managed drinking water services (SDG 6.1.1)". Concernant les niveaux de services, le Fonds ANE renseigne ici le niveau "basique" selon les niveaux de services du Programme commun OMS/UNICEF de suivi de l’approvisionnement en eau, de l’assainissement et d’hygiène (JMP). Suivant ces niveaux, le service "basique" correspond à un " Point d’eau amélioré", telle une borne Fontaine (BF), situé entre 15 et 30 minutes aller-retour du domicile et dont l'eau est disponible 10 à 11 mois par an. Au vu des critères du JMP, Le Fonds ANE considère que les kiosques et FPM créés ou réhabilités par les projets ont un niveau basique. (Le nombre d'écoliers ayant accès à l'eau au niveau des kiosques à eau construits dans les écoles ne sont pas comptabilisé au niveau de cet indicateur). La cible finale de cet indicateur est 133.500 personnes dont 70.000 femmes. Milieu rural : 44.000 personnes dont 23.000 femmes ; et milieu urbain : 89.500 personnes dont 46.000 femmes.

comment.narrative: Cet indicateur mesurant le progrès, aucune personne n’a bénéficié d’une amélioration des conditions d’accès à l’eau potable à l’étape de l’étude de référence. Toutefois l’état de la situation actuelle par niveau de services est renseigné dans le Rapport annuel 2018.

Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l'année 2018, le Fonds ANE vise 22.500 personnes dont 7.500 en milieu rural et 15.000 en milieu urbain. 52% sont considérées comme étant des femmes.

01-04-2020: Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l'année 2018, le Fonds a atteint 18.750 personnes dont 9.750 femmes en milieu urbain

Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l'année 2020, le Fonds ANE vise 25.000 personnes dont 14.000 femmes ; milieu rural = 5.000 dont 3.000 femmes ; milieu urbain = 20.000 dont 11.000 femmes.

24-02-2021: Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l'année 2020, le Fonds ANE a atteint 61.500 dont 31.980 femmes. Milieu rural = 41.500 personnes dont 21.580 femmes ; et milieu urbain = 20.000 personnes dont 10.400 femmes. La cible a été largement dépassée notamment car les 2 projets Covid et les activités Covid menées par les projets des composantes AEPHA et GIRE ont permis de contribuer à hauteur de 18.000 personnes dont 9.360 femmes en milieu rural pour ce résultat, ce qui n'était évidemment pas prévu.

Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l'année 2019, le Fonds ANE vise 86.000 personnes dont 44.000 femmes ; milieu rural = 44.000 dont 23.000 femmes ; milieu urbain = 42.000 dont 21.000 femmes.

26-02-2020: Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l'année 2019, le Fonds ANE a atteint 89.400 personnes dont 46.488 femmes. Milieu rural = 38.750 personnes dont 20.150 femmes ; et milieu urbain = 50.650 personnes dont 26.338 femmes.
Les ouvrages doivent tous avoir été créés et réhabilités d'ici la fin 2020 permettant l'accès aux personnes ciblées.

title.narrative: 1c. Nombre de personnes (h/f) utilisant des services d’alimentation en eau potable au niveau de lieux publics (urbain/rural)

description.narrative: Cet indicateur du Fonds ANE, peut aussi permettre de renseigner l'indicateur de DGIS / EKN "Number of people using safely managed drinking water services (SDG 6.1.1)". Cet indicateur a été ajouté suite aux réorientations : sont dénombrés ici le nombre de personnes additionnelles ayant accès à l’eau potable au niveau d’un lieu public (marchés, gares, sanimarchés, péages). La cible finale de cet indicateur est 6.500 dont 3.800 femmes. Milieu rural : 0 et milieu urbain : 6.500 dont 3.380 femmes.

comment.narrative: L'état de la situation actuelle pour les ouvrages en milieu public ont été renseignés directement au niveau des projets.

Les cibles et résultats par année sont estimés sur la base des réalisations des organisations exécutantes mais les résultats définitifs seront renseignés suite à la collecte des données finales des projets. Pour l’année 2020, la cible est de 6.500 personnes dont 3.400 femmes.

24-02-2021: Sont dénombrés ici le nombre de personnes additionnelles ayant accès à l’eau potable au niveau d’un lieu public (marchés, gares, sanimarchés, péages). Protos, avait prévu de réaliser des points d'eau dans les lieux publics mais finalement les écoles ont été priorisées car le besoin était plus important. Toutefois, bien que cela touche moins de personnes (environ 200 élèves contre 500 personnes dans les espaces publics) la cible finale est atteinte car Helvetas a quant à lui réalisé 05 kiosques en eau supplémentaires au niveau des blocs sanitaires publics. Ainsi, pour l'année 2020, le Fonds ANE a atteint 6.500 personnes dont 3.380 femmes en milieu urbain uniquement.
Cet indicateur a été ajouté en 2019 suite aux réorientations des activités dues aux réformes du sous-secteur de l'Approvisionnement en Eau Potable.

Les kiosques publics doivent tous avoir été créés d'ici la fin 2020 permettant l'accès aux personnes ciblées.
